ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: depending on week. probably like 8-10, in the beginning of the term it was mostly time for readings, later time for work added, so from the mid tetm it was much more.
4 or 5 hours a week.
Maybe 5?
8h
Workload varied but average time spent reading per week was 2-3 hours. On weeks with assignments, time spent was closer to between 4-7 hours depending on the assignment.
6-8 hours
It depended on the assignment that was due that week. Some weeks I spent 10+hours and others only a few. Though it was a lot at times it was also very managable.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: everything was great. logistically, provided enough knowledge and resources to learn how to make a qualitative research I liked guests who came to share their experience. atmosphere was always friendly. I liked everything

This course was an amazing learning experience. I had the chance to take a research project from beginning to end and to learn about all of the components of qualitative research. I really appreciated that Danya broke the research process down into parts to make such a large project manageable, and I felt accomplished at the end of the semester.

This is a very practical course with an excellent instructor. Perfect for students who want to do qualitative research projects for their summer internships. It was fun! Just make sure to pick a good group as the whole class is group-based assignments.
High workload. A lot of group assignments. Friday afternoon class schedule is not welcomed.

I really enjoyed this class. I was a nice break from the quantitative coursework and very enlightening to the core purpose and rationale behind qualitative research in the social science/public health arena. It definitely helped prepare me for my summer internship project and provided me with a lot of skills that I hope to perfect as time goes on. As for improvements, I found the section on coding to be somewhat confusing--I am not sure how it could be better taught but more examples might be useful. I also think that having interviews completed prior to spring break and the assignment linked to them due right after spring break was highly stressful and not conducive to an enjoyable spring break or well produced product. The timeline could have been shifted to move the actual interviews closer to the PO so that the coding for both of those happens closer together and prior to spring break. Just a thought.

Great course. One of the best courses I took this semester. I learned a lot of tangible skills that I can apply to my research in the future. The class structure was very well organized and class time was spent efficiently.

This course integrated conceptual learning with practice and implementation incredibly well. I was able to learn through doing and through studying and found that to be very conducive to my understanding of qualitative research.

In a seminar this size, I don't usually find the small group activities super useful. Would rather just discuss as a class. Otherwise I felt the format worked well. Personally I would have liked the course to be a little more challenging in terms of quality of output, but the feedback we got was still useful and I still learned a lot.
This course is an excellent introduction to qualitative research. I felt well prepared for future qualitative research after taking this course.
Quite a great course but the timing for some assignments were quite annoying as it did not leave you enough time to learn it all.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Danya Keene  Danya Keene is excellent teacher, smart, sensitive to questions, ready to be flexible within the needed frames, with a lot of energy. It is obvious that she likes what she is doing and it maked me like a lot qualitative approach

Instructor: Danya Keene  Danya is amazing! She is super well-organized, gives very specific and helpful comments, is responsive, smart, and willing to share her own learning process with us. I can't even think of any ways her teaching could be improved.
Instructor: Danya Keene  She is great. Very receptive to students' needs and provides continual and helpful feedback. Also willing to meet with students during and outside of office hours.
Instructor: Danya Keene  She is responsive and willing to help students. It would be great if the class can be less boring.

Instructor: Danya Keene  Danya was great! Most of her lectures were informative and well-organized. I also like the guest speakers she brought it as they all provided interesting and unique perspectives on aspects of qualitative research. She also works hard to be accessible to students, which was greatly appreciated. We sometimes didn't get to through all of the material she had prepared, but we had a lot of interesting conversations...

Instructor: Danya Keene  Great instructor. Provide very valuable feedback throughout the entire course and was open to meeting beyond normal office hours. Showed genuine interest in subject matter and students.
Instructor: Danya Keene  This was a wonderful class with a wonderful professor. She provided feedback quickly and in very useful ways.
Instructor: Danya Keene  Danya is amazing. So thoughtful and helpful in every way. She made the course interesting and informative.
Instructor: Danya Keene  Fantastic professor! Gave very helpful feedback and lectures were engaging.
Instructor: Danya Keene  Danya was very accessible and responsive. She did a great job leading class discussions on interesting topics. She also choose great guest speakers for this course.
Instructor: Danya Keene  Excellent professor.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend the course is about how to conduct a qualitative research from the beging till the end.

This course is a great opportunity to take ownership over a project and to learn A LOT about qualitative research in the process. Take it if you have any interest in learning about this kind of research, especially if you would love to do original qualitative research on a topic over the course of the semester. Classes were well-organized, guest lectures were interesting, and all of the assignments helped build to a final paper and presentation.
A good course to learn qualitative research method.
Really comprehensive course for those who are interested in qualitative research in Public Health

This course involved a significant amount of group work. You work to development of a qualitative research tool set including semi-structured interview question development/administration, participant observation, and coding/thematic analysis, all using grounded theory. If you are interested in these types of skills, I highly recommend it! Also be prepared to be learn about a very different approach and mindset to research.
Great course. I HIGHLY recommend it to students who are interested in conducting qualitative research.
Choose your group wisely. You spend a lot of time working with them and that can make or break your experience.
Take this course! A must for anyone doing qual research
Great way to learn or practice qualitative methods as they are used in public health. Not as much work as it appears from the syllabus, and you can pick a topic you're interested in.
I would absolutely recommend this course to other students, unless they have no interest in conducting qualitative research.
Yes because quite helpful and great practice for the summer.
